Award.AbstractNarration: This award is to (1) develop a numerical model of Interhemispherical Field-Aligned Currents (IHCs) flowing between polar ionospheres in two hemispheres, (2) examine expected effects of these currents on geomagnetic activity, ionosphere, and upper atmosphere in the polar regions in both hemispheres, and (3) compare the modeling results with experimental data. The IHCs flow between the Northern and Southern high-latitude ionospheres exists predominantly due to differences in the ionospheric conductivity of the respective polar regions. Due to the Earth's orientation, the northern summer (southern winter) these interhemispherical currents can be very strong and comparable in magnitude with the total field-aligned currents (FACs) flowing in and out of the respective hemispheres at the specific Universal Time (UT) intervals. While crossing an equatorial plane, the IHCs do not change their direction; and as a result, they may increase the total FACs strength in one hemisphere, but decrease it in the opposite hemisphere. This can lead to the strong asymmetry in the total FACs system, as well as to specific geomagnetic and ionospheric disturbances in the two polar regions. The research will bring better understanding of interhemispherical asymmetry in the FACs system, northern and southern auroras, and ionospheric disturbances and UT variations in geomagnetic activity. The proposed model of interhemispherical currents would also be an important component of the set of Space Weather models, improving space weather forecasts of geomagnetic and ionospheric disturbances over two hemispheres and their potential effects on the low-orbiting spacecraft.

POR.DRECONTENT:
On my NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship ANT-1204019 "Asymmetry in geomagnetic activity in two hemispheres and interhemispheric field-aligned currents", I worked aiming two major goals:

  1. Developing a numerical model of three-dimensional magnetosphere-ionosphere current system, including Interhemispheric Field-Fligned Currents (IHCs) flowing between conjugate polar ionospheres,

  2. Developing and teaching a scientific course that provides real science experience with computer modeling, computing, and performing a numerical analysis for undergraduate students of Howard Community College, Columbia, MD.

 

Developing the Model

The first goal of this work was the study of the IHCs and examining their effect in two hemispheres. These currents are flowing between two hemispheres along the magnetic field lines; they are generated when there is a difference (asymmetry) in ionospheric conductivities in two conjugate ionospheres, which occurs particularly due to different solar luminosity in two hemispheres during summer-winter conditions and some universal time intervals. These currents can be significant and comparable in magnitude with the Region 1 field-aligned currents, which is the major current system that transports the energy from the solar wind into our magnetosphere and ionosphere. Though the IHCs were observed many times, they were not sufficiently studied and estimated yet. Therefore, this research allowed providing a scientific community with this new important information.

The research included the following objectives:

  1. Developing a numerical model of the IHCs for different conditions in two hemispheres

  2. Using this model for investigation of: (i) the contribution of these currents to total three-dimensional currents system during different conditions, (ii) the contribution of the IHCs to seasonal and other variations of geomagnetic activity in two hemispheres, and (iii) the magnitude and distribution of these currents for different conditions which can effect heating of high-latitude ionosphere and the distribution of ionospheric and equivalent ionospheric currents (the latter describe geomagnetic disturbances under the ionosphere) in two hemispheres.

The obtained results indicate that the IHCs is an important component of the global current system and may significantly affects geomagnetic disturbances and auroral events in two hemispheres. Taking IHCs into account gives better understanding and more accurate computing of the global current system and improve the prediction reliability of geomagnetic and ionospheric disturbances.

The resuts of the research are published in two papers (one more paper is in preparation):

  1. Lyatskaya, S., G.V.Khazanov, and E.Zesta (2014), Interhemispheric Field-Aligned Currents: Simulation Results, Journal of Geophysical Research, doi:10.1002/2013JA019558.

  2. Lyatskaya, S., W.Lyatsky, and G.V.Khazanov (2014), Effect of Interhemispheric Field-Aligned Currents on Region-1 Currents, Geophysical Research Letters., 41, 3731–3737, doi:10.1002/2014GL060413.

and presented at ten various events: AGU, GEM / CEDAR conferences, JGU APL and NASA GSFC presentations and workshops.
